div.p:
Anonymity was a great possession. It gave the early
plays writing a general nature. It (t) gave us the ballads (ballds); it gave
us the songs (somgs). It allowed us to know nothing of the mans
name. had great privileges. He is not responsible.
He is not self conscious. He can borrow. He can repeat.
He can say what everyone feels. No one asks that he shall
stamp his own name on his work. He keeps at a distance from
the present moment. Anon the lyric writer repeats (repeat) over and
over (ove) again that flowers fade; that death is the end.
He is never tired of celebrating (clebrating) red roses and the white
breast (bresast) of his mistress. The anonymous dxmxmxmxmxmx
playwright has like the singer this nameless (namless) vitality.
something drawn from the crowd in the penny seats. and not
yet dead in ourselves (ouslves). For we too have become anonymous (aninymous), and
forget something that we have learnt, in reading the plays
that no one troubled to set a name to.

Later when the audience becomes critical, when the
emotion in the audience becomes self conscious (oncsious), when
the country squire can say without quoting what
is in his mind, we lose this general quality to gain---
everything it seems (seemes). For until the shut the theatre (thea)
the curtain (curayin) rises incessantly (incesaantly). It goes on rising until
finally it rises on the . But by then the stage has
become too small for the play. It has outgrown the uncovered
theatre where the (eh) sun beats and the rain pours. And the
reader is born. He acts the play in the theatre of his own
brain. Perhaps after centuries the play is born again,

revealed, is often a suspended (supended) derelict irrelevant beauty.
There is no sequence. It does not connect; axxxx the
rxmxmxmxmxf the parts are u severed (sevred), and something runs to
waste. For the anonuymous playwright is irresponsible (irrepsonsible).
He flouts truth (trith) at the bidding of the audience. he cares only (ony)
for the plot. We are left in the end without an end. The
emotion is wasted.

But gradually the audience is mastered by the playwright (playwrgiht).
The mist withdraws. So many dramatists (darmatists) are exploring (explroing)
tunnels that lead at last to some common discovery (disocvery).
So many private people are pressing their weight of
unexpressed (eunexpressed) emotion upon the writers consciousness (consciouness).
Country squires are learning (earning) to speak what they feel without
quoting Spenser. The curtain rises on play after (afte) play.
Each time it rises upon a more detached, a more matured
drama. The individual (indivisual) on the stage becomes more and more
differentiated (diife entiated); and the whole group is more closely
related (rleated) and less at the mercy of the lp plot. The curtain
rises upon Hxmxmmxmx ; and ;
upon and and upon .
Finally it rises upon the Tempest. But the play has outgrown
the uncovered theatre where the sun (s n) beats and the rain
pours. That theatre (thetare) must be replaced by the
theatre (thestre) of the brain. The playwright is replaced by the man
who writes a book. The audience is replaced by the reader.
Anon is dead.

The audience at the Elizabethan (Elizabetahn) play was not an (audiejce)
of readers. They had to draw in (int) the play through their ears, through their eyes
They could not deepen the impression and renew
it at a table in a private room. This perhaps explains
the scarcity of Elizabethan criticism; and the general nature
of what criticism there is. Both and
deal with the general rules of poetry; not with the particular (particuar)
play or poem. The lack of a book of the words accounts too
for the long pause, between death
and the eighteenth century, when (whe) the plays of Shakespeare (Shakepere)
even hang suspended, unrealised (unrea ised). They had to wait until the
printed book was in many hands before they received
the life that the reader confers (co fers) Much that was lost
in the playhouse was discovered (disocvered) in the private room.
But much (mu h) was lost for ever when the playhouse shut.
Txmxmmxmxmxmxmmxmxmxmmxmxmxmxmxm We have lost the sound of the
spoken word; all that the sight of the actors bodies
suggests to the mind through the eye. We have lost the
sense of being part of the audience. We miss a thousand (th usnd)
suggestions that the dramatist conveyed by the inflection
of voice, by gesture, by the placing of the actors bodies.
This can still be proved by comparing our impression
after (aft) seeing the play acted with our impression after reading
the play alone. But as the actor imports (ipmports) much that is of
his own day, and [foreign?] (foreing) to the past, so that there is t
still something in every Elizabethan play sunk beyond recall.

Presumably the earlier plays, in which the playwright
and the audience were mxxxx in closer cooperation, are the
more damaged by reading them. The reader instinctively (instinctivly) tries
to be there in person. He tries to supply the trumpets
and the flags; the citizens and the apprentices. He
nourishes the inadequate (inadeuate) emotion with a dip into ,
with a dip into . He labours to supply the sunk
part of the play. He is perpetually (perpetaully) rebuffed. He is apt
to become not a reader but a student; a careful (crafeul) collector of
old scattered bones. At some point however in Elizabethan
drama the readerr is born. When the dramatist becomes (beceomes) consi
of the play as a work of art; when he is able to unite the
play by something in himself--his personality, his
conception-- it is then that, he brings the reader into being (beig)

We can be sure then that the reader has been
in existence for round about four hundred years. But his
life history is an obscure one. At some point his ear must
have lost its (i s) acuteness (acutness); then his eyes (eyees) became dulled.
Later he became more conscious of the suggestions and echoes
in words. He imported much into the written (w itten) word that was
unintended xxxxxxx by the writer. A word given in its
Elizabethan spelling brings in suggestions that give it
almost another meaning. The words suggest other manners,
other clothes. They accent the contrast between one society
and another. And as the habit of reading becomes universal,
many varieties (varities) of reader are created. There are the
specialised (s ecialised) readers whose power of drawing (darwing) out the
